repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Agricultural Services Sub sector
            Investment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Agricultural Services
            Sub sector Investment Project for Ghana were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderately, the Bank performance was
            moderate satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            moderate satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            combining in one operation: (i) investment lending for a
            very large number of activities; and (ii) a broad
            institutional reform agenda concerning several centralized
            and decentralized organizations. Accelerating mid-term
            reviews when governments have changed: for a major
            sub-sector loan with several distinct policy orientations
            and institutional reform objectives, the election cycle must
            be taken into account in establishing the time line for the
            different steps in loan processing (Board presentation and
            effectiveness) and the expected time for implementation.
            Donor coordination and parallel financing: although
            ultimately donor coordination is the borrowers
            responsibility, in this kind of operation where success is
            to a certain extent predicated on better donor coordination,
            specific mechanisms for collaboration, including process
            mechanisms, procedures, and leadership arrangements will be
            explicitly and formally discussed and agreed upon by donor
            representatives in the field as well as their headquarters
            at the outset of the project. In addition, securing
            availability of other sources of funds during project
            preparation is critical for ensuring the coherence and
            integrity of the overall financing plan. Otherwise the
            program cost and design should be adjusted accordingly
            before International Development Association (IDA) approval.

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Agricultural Services Subsector
            Investment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Services Subsector
            Investment Project aims at a) initiating and accelerating
            policy and institutional reforms for the strengthening of
            Government's capacity; b) decentralizing the planning
            and implementation of agricultural development programs to
            the regions and districts; c) promoting cost-effective
            demand-driven agricultural and extension systems to generate
            and disseminate technologies on a contracting and/or cost
            sharing basis; and d) strengthening the capacity of
            farmers-based organizations. The project consists of four
            components. 1) Reforming and strengthening agricultural
            technology generation and diffusion as the main thrust of
            the program will accelerate agricultural growth that results
            in increased food security, reduced poverty, and
            conservation of the natural resource base. 2) Institutional
            reform and strengthening of Ministry of Food and Agriculture
            (MOFA) will integrate resources for implementation of plans
            and provision of decentralized services under the
            administration of district assemblies, thus placing the
            responsibility for planning and implementation of
            agricultural services and development activities at the
            grassroots level. 3) Development of farmer-based
            organizations (FBOs) will develop a grassroots independent
            movement of FBOs. 4) Strengthening agricultural education
            and training will strengthen the capacity of agricultural
            training institutions to produce the middle level human
            resources/skills critically needed in the sector.

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Agricultural Subsector Services
            Investment Program Project - environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This strategic environmental assessment
            is required, as the Agricultural Services Sector Investment
            Project covers three sectoral, regional, and indirect
            issues: reforming agricultural technology generation;
            institutional strengthening, and reform of the Ministry of
            Food and Agriculture; and, development of farmer-based
            organizations, which includes agricultural training. The
            project, mainly service, and research oriented, could
            generate adverse agricultural interventions on the
            environment, such as bio-diversity loss, and land, and water
            resources degradation, resulting in soil fertility loss, and
            erosion. Mitigating measures specify that: 1) degradation of
            productive systems affecting crops, would be compensated
            through a built-in natural resource management program, to
            match crop species with site suitability criteria.
            Fertilizer trials will recommend appropriate dosage, and
            application for specific types of soil; 2) agricultural
            technology diffusion, will refocus on the management of
            natural resources in the provision of environmental
            extension services, through improved soil, and water
            conservation methods, and include community participation;
            3) improvement of communal grazing areas, monitoring of
            improved breeds, and, application of non-polluting methods
            for tsetse control, will curtail endangered livestock; and,
            4) aquatic fauna will be monitored, and culture effluents
            will be bio-restored.
